Description: Scarab carved from whitish steatite; back relatively well-defined with simply marked head and clypeus, prothorax and elytra divisions shown by single incised lines; small triangles indicating humeral callosities as well as scutellum behind the line of prothorax; at side, well-shaped legs with undercut triangle; underside incised with very schematic representation of a seated god holding a Hes vase; god wearing a long false beard and a crown composed of a mortar surmonted by two vertical feathers; pierced longitudinally; slightly chipped on edge.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
This scarab is published as coming from Naukratis (Budge 1893, no.165). Budge, E.A.W.1893, Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge.

The motto starting with 'hsy' - praised by - is very common on Egyptian scarabs, especially the inscription ‘praised by Khonsu’ and ‘praised by Amun’. The deity following the Hes-vase bears a double ostrich-feather crown and could be identified with Amun-Ra. For a similar motto on other stone scarabs from Naukratis: Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.12; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.864. By its size, style, technique and theme, this finely made miniature scarab fits Gorton's type VIII, a type well attested on Punic and Etruscan sites in the West, as well as in Greece and Cyprus (Gorton 1996, type VIII, 23-7). Gorton suggested that such scarabs were produced in Memphis, from the 8th till the 7th c. BC (Gorton 1996, 27). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Budge 1893b / Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum (no. 165)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.70) (phase 3)
